page.title: 06Lighthouse
page.content: When meetings were held in 1635 to discuss the possibility of erecting a light on the Isle of May it was suggested that Inchkeith should also have one. However a lighthouse was not erected on Inchkeith until 1803. It was a pioneer in its field as the light was fitted with reflectors made of copper and plated with silver and it used spermaceti oil rather than whale oil. Above the entrance is a plaque, which states:{"For the {direction of mariners, and for the {benefit of commerce, this lighthouse {was erected by order of the {Commissioners of the Northern {Lighthouses. It was founded on the {18th day of May in the year 1803, and {lighted on the 14th of September 1804. {Thomas Smith, Engineer."}In October 1835 the first dioptric light in Britain shone from Inchkeith.
